commentBody:
Sam, it's not just that AL are the first two letters of the theme answers.

AL is the state postal code for ALABAMA.

AL is the chemical symbol for ALUMINUM.

AL is a common nickname for ALBERT.

Which makes it one step more clever than before.

My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Way of getting online that might sound like "beep beep beeHAW beeHAW beeeeeep SHRHRHRHRH"  (6)
2. Screenwriter's way of re-introducing some characters?  (5)
3. Turning point in telecommunications history?  (6)(4)
4. Stressed half the time, say  (6)
5. When doubled, something seen atop a pyramid?  (3)


DIALUP
PASTE
ROTARY DIAL
IAMBIC
POM
Seeing Albert Brooks' name brought a big smile to my face.
HUNDO?  ONBLAST?  I'm way behind the times (sigh).  Both were new to me.

A wonderful memory from the 1991 Paul Simon concert in Central Park was when Chevy Chase joined Paul on stage to recreate the 'You Can Call Me Al' video. The crowd went wild. 

I really like how the theme references the postal, chemical and name abbreviations for AL. So clever!

Congratulations on your debut, Elliot.

Super fun and fast after yesterday‚Äôs challenge that I just barely finished before this one dropped. Two of my favorite movies and my favorite song in high school (I may or may not have called my h.s. girlfriend Betty, and well, you know what she called me).

Congratulations on a nice debut, Elliot Caroll!

As Sam Corbin noted, this is a wonderful puzzle for someone who's just starting out solving.
Annoying Monday
OL√Å again. You‚Äôre welcome üòâ.

Is it just me who had never seen the word liaise before today?

I knew the noun liaison but not the back-formation.

Fun puzzle! (Even though I didn't know the theme song)
Thank you for a fun Monday puzzle!  I hope to see more of Elliot Caroll's creations!

Retiring You Can Call Me Al?  Because of hearing loss?

It's practically a spoken word song.  I don't get it.  Sad in any case. I hope he improves...


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
I am finding this difficult for a Monday puzzle. It's nice to have one puzzle you can just bang out. Not this one.

Fun, pretty quick one! Faster than average Monday but not my fastest. Though, I was able to fill in the revealer without having any of its crossings. Grew up with that album (born in 86 and my dad was a big fan of it).

Any puzzle with a TIARA in it is okay by me. And Paul Simon.  The Call me Al video is one of the ones that I play in the morning to convince myself to get out of bed. 
And who in the 1990s can forget wanting Beanie Babies or having to hunt them down? Working in Manhattan,  I was tasked with locating the harder to find ones for my nieces' Christmas presents. 

Also, working in a law firm during that time, I can say that Nuts the Squirrel was a very popular desk toy for attorneys and support staff with a sense of humor.  I still have mine. 

Congrats on publication, Elliott

There must be at least "50 Ways to Clue a Crossword," but hundo was a new one for me.  I guess I'll make a new plan, Stan - whoever he is.

Wishing you a smiled-filled week and smooth sailing puzzle adventures.
Great debut, Elliot! Congratulation!
Enjoyed this debut!  Another one, please?

One of the most fun Mondays I‚Äôve seen In a while.  I love Paul Simon, and ALthough YOUCANCALLMEAL, is not one of my favorite songs of his (I‚Äôm more of a Rhythm Of The Saints fan), it was great to see that song used as part of a clever Monday theme.  I‚Äôm also a big fan of ALBERTBROOKS, whose quirky, lowkey films like Defending Your Life, Mother, and Lost In America are quite charming.  I also like cocktails, ALthough I can‚Äôt vouch for the ALABAMASLAMMER, as that‚Äôs one I‚Äôve never tried, as I more of a traditional cocktail maker.  ALL in ALL, this one was right up my ALLey.
Very enjoyable Monday puzzle. I finished this in just about exactly my Monday average time. And I always enjoy it when constructors respond to comments here.
Now I understand why Americans can‚Äôt pronounce aluminium correctly - sniff

Said one leftover to another, "Foiled again!"

(And that's a wrap!)
Not a fun Monday for me.   Thought this was supposed to be the easiest to solve.   Didn't like this one at all.

What was that? L

The mix of trivia and unmonday-like misdirection in the clues was truly unpleasant this early in the week. I can only imagine how a beginner must have felt facing this grid.

I think I'm fairly experienced by now, but I solved this in a time above my Tuesday average, and slower than my fastest Saturday. I was so annoyed I actually looked up two pieces of trivia to be done with the grid.

I want to relax on a Monday, not be challenged, so this was by far one of my least favorite NYT puzzles ever. If this ran on a Tuesday perhaps I would have been less critical, but c'mon, it's Monday!
X and y on a graph is axis, not axes. Axes are tools

I enjoyed this, especially the reminder of the song. The HUNDO/YEUN crossing was a bit of a Natick for me because I thought that U might be an O, and tried it that way first. I hadn't heard of the ALABAMA SLAMMER and couldn't remember FARSI at this time of night, but I got them from crosses. 

Congratulations on the debut!
Personally found it really, really, tough for a Monday. Relatively new crossword solver but first Monday in a little bit that I wasn‚Äôt able to solve completely.

With the exception of IONIZE and ALUMINIUM the SPELLing bee seems to have gone well üôÑ

A Monday afternoon puzzle in terms of difficulty 

I have a blackboard in my office but I don‚Äôt know that I have a HOOP and what‚Äòs a POG?

Liked the puzzle. Although I've done a few Tuesdays faster I didn't find it as difficult as some others noted. Love a Paul Simon clue. There were a few tight spots but it fell into place with a small amount of lateral thinking. Probably filmdom was the stretchiest and least satisfying clue of the bunch but most puzzles have one or two of those. Nice to see a fellow Canadian around here!

Especially fun because our cruise ship was just pulling out of a gimme for me, NASSAU, as I filled this out! We do so love vast blue expanses!!

A hair or two slower than I've been running for Monday but no good reason why...  Hmm, maybe the day drinking....  Har!  Maybe tomorrow I'll see about an ALABAMASLAMMER! And I might just request YOUCANCALLMEAL in the piano bar tomorrow night!!

But seriously, a charming theme and a pleasure to complete!

Congrats and thanks for a sparkly fun debut!!

Bah-dum-dum-dum! Love that song, love the video. (Remember when Chevy Chase was fun?) But most of all, I love Albert Brooks. While he has never received the National Treasure status he deserves, I am delighted he was chosen here to represent the ALs. Ms. Caroll clearly has excellent taste.

As for the difficulty of the puzzle, I agree that it required a bit more thought than the usual Monday, but I appreciated that! Besides, anything I had to skip over initially was amply aided by the crosses. I thought it was a great start to the week. And it made me smile more than once, so thanks, Elliot!
This was a terrific puzzle, Elliot, debut or otherwise.  Nice use of the three different meanings of AL.  I'm looking forward to more.

Nice Monday puzzle and glad to see our new constructor. Anyway... a bit on the slow side for a Monday for me, and was almost done before I caught on at all to the theme, so that was a nice touch. Looking forward to more from Ms. Caroll. A couple of puzzle finds today, of course. The first one - a Tuesday from June 26, 2001 by Stephen Windheim. I remain puzzled by this one. Anyway... three long across answers, all straightforwardly clued: TICKETTORIDE TACITAPPROVAL TOERRISHUMAN And then... what I guess is the 'reveal.' "A winning combination in today's puzzle theme." OOO I am not grasping that at all. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/26/2001&g=58&d=A ....

Cool puzzle. A bit more difficult that most Mondays, and I welcome that, so I thank the editors for placing Elliot Caroll's well-constructed puzzle here.

Paul Simon is one of the great US songwriters, right alongside Frank Zappa and Bob Dylan. The greatest North American songwriter is Neil Young, and I have a special fondness for Leonard Cohen and Lou Reed.

Albert Brooks has created some excellent films. I enjoy his wry take on life, particularly in Modern Romance and Lost In America, which are two American classics. (I do wonder whether anyone has ever called him "Al" -- I haven't watched the documentary yet, so that might be a way to find out.) Plus, Brooks's brother, the late Bob Einstein, is one of the funniest guys ever, so I was happy to think about him as well, particularly his years on Curb Your Enthusiasm.

Why do some people still call aluminum foil "tin foil"? I have read any studies on this, but I suspect those people also say "ink pen" and perhaps even "icebox". If you say "tin foil" I'd be interested in a response, because my curiosity is now piqued.

Alabama Slammers will remain a mystery to me. I gave up alcohol 5+ years ago, because it was enough already, but if I ever have a terminal disease, I will welcome bourbon back into what remains of my life.

And now with YSSY playing in the background via Bandcamp, I'll continue through the rest of the NYT Monday puzzles.

For some reason Eric the Actor just popped into my head, so I'll say, "Bye for now."

This was a fine debut puzzle, but in my opinion not a Monday puzzle.  At least I wasn‚Äôt the only one who thought that.  

It was fun to hear so much from Elliot and I look forward to see what she comes up with next.

Lovely debut!

Got my Paul Simon,
ANNE of Green Gables, and
SPELLing bees!

Fun clueing!
Deep in a pit! Bring it on!

Thank you Eliot! 
I‚Äôd be a sad, incompetent bodyguard, but 
Congratulations!
Oh great.  I get to have that song stuck in my head all day.

Here‚Äôs the official Call Me Al video with Paul Simon and Chevy Chase https://youtu.be/uq-gYOrU8bA?si=WVwWjIw8L1nZ5cYd ‚Ä¶ and from a concert in Hyde Park: https://youtu.be/PS-sE9xCb-g?si=g8SktFDSZ1ttUtjr

Delightful debut! Smooth solve with a simple, charming, Monday-appropriate theme. Several of the clues evoked nostalgia for the times in my life when I first encountered them - the Graceland album, the Anne Shirley books, even (somewhat embarrassingly) the Alabama slammer. Welcome, Eliot!

Fun puzzle!
The theme quickly clicked for me. I think I had an edge.
Not a PB, but one I'll remember!
15A. I read it as BLACKBOARD attachment, so filling in the crosses had me wondering.
I too found it difficult for a Monday...but an enjoyable puzzle. Also had trouble with hundo and Dae..and I don't find aluminum foil crinkly?

This one blazed with spark:  
‚Ä¢	Three of the four theme answers being NYT debut answers, and the fourth (ALUMINUM FOIL) only appearing four times before in 80+ years.  
‚Ä¢	Lovely answers, such as LAP UP, HUNDO, LIAISE, CRUX, and ALABAMA SLAMMER. 
‚Ä¢	Freshness in cluing, such the colorful clue that enlivened the humdrum answer MUCH: [Shania Twain‚Äôs ‚ÄúThat Don‚Äôt Impress Me ___‚Äù]. 
‚Ä¢	The theme itself, three words commonly shortened to AL, given the perfect revealer.  
‚Ä¢	Even an end-of-week terrific riddle clue, [What‚Äôs deep in the pit?] for TUBA.

Combining spark like this with the relative ease of a Monday fill-in had a serious ‚ÄúWhee!‚Äù vibe.  Sure, Mondays fill in quickly for me, a veteran solver, but the splat-fill often feels rote, with oft-seen clues and answers and a bland theme.  But when spark peppers a brisk solve, suddenly that solve becomes thrilling, and in a way that can only happen very early in the week.

That‚Äôs what I got from you today, Elliot, and on your NYT debut, no less (Congratulations!).  You‚Äôve blasted me into the day ahead, and pleeeze come back with more.  Thank you so much for this!

Elliot, I'll echo what others have said: more difficult than the usual Monday--but in a good way; I picked up the "abbreviation," not the simple "opening two letters," level of the theme. By way of thanks, here's a short playlist, for you to download onto your iPod: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o6bpS45cdw4 (something a little stronger than a Slammer) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=urglg3WimHA (Sorry, I don't know enough abut Mr. Brooks for him to give me an ear-worm.)

BEANIE babies brought back a sweet memory from when our daughter Emily was seven.  This was when Beanie Babies were at their height, and she simply had to have one.  There was no guarantee, and she knew it, because she knew how hard they were to find in stores.

But come Christmas, she opened the package and there it was!   Emily was the picture of ecstasy, of a life fulfilled.

Until it was clear that the doll was defective.  It didn‚Äôt talk!  Emily‚Äôs ebullience quickly morphed into deep despair, the culmination of which was her sitting on the couch with the doll in her lap, singing haltingly through tears, from ‚ÄúAnnie‚Äù, ‚ÄúThe sun will come out, tomorrow‚Ä¶‚Äù  The whole song.  

This is a family story now, and it‚Äôs stories like this that are the textures of our lives.

Albert Brooks‚Äô birth name was Albert Einstein, also a famous Al.  But US courts wouldn‚Äôt let his father change his own name from Harry Einstein to Parkyakarkus.  Boy did Harry Einstein‚Äôs generation know how to get buzz.

I appreciated the two answers hanging side-by-side in the top left: comfy, loose pull-ons beside the unwise pair that causes damage.

Nice, tight puzzle!

Nice puzzle. Not only do all the theme entries begin with AL but the first words are all ones that are regularly shortened to AL (or Al). Together with the song, that's a winner of a theme. 

I've been working on constructing puzzles now for a couple of years, but my themes are all kind of MEH. And I won't even start on the frustration of filling in the grid, where all is going well until I get to an unresolvable area that undoes the many hours I've already spent getting there. In his comments, Elliot alludes to the pain of bulldozing a nearly completed puzzle.  What I'd like to know is how to tell when it's time to bulldoze, rather than continuing the battle to make the previous fill work, when it's never gonna happen.
It always amuses me how you guys can get away with omitting entire syllables from ‚Äúaluminium‚Äù üòä
Great debut with some fun TIL's (ONBLAST, NOR, RACCOON City).  Well done and thanks.

We were impaled on IMPAIR.  Otherwise we survived.

The puz brought to mind the nightly adventures of the RACCOONS  in our yard.  They play well with the feral cats.

Thank you Elliot.

Glad others found it a little tricksy for Monday, I thought my last little grey cell had expired.
Must. Remember. UK/US spelling/pronunciation of ALUMINIuM. Holds me up every time. 
ON BLAST a new one for me, plus of course I only know about RACCOONS from myriad US films/comedies/dramas. I love the term ‚Äòtrash bandit‚Äô. It was pesky seagulls when we lived nearer the coast. The noisy sky rats could get into any bin so the council handed out huge, canvas bags with heavy duty buckles. Worked well but didn‚Äôt stop the blighters trying. 

A great debut puzzle. I love the AL theme and how you connected such disparate things as a song title, a cocktail and a kitchen aid. Kudos.

Before they were transferred, our minor league team played against the "Trash Pandas"--which never failed to crack me up.  

I didn't go back to look, but I assume the emus never released my Sunday post re ELAN (clued as "Gusto"....more than a stretch) which had included my illustrative anecdote.  Pfft to emus.

Today's CLUNK:  $100 = HUNDO.  DHubby joins me in UGHing.

I always reverse the last two letters in the "online source for cinephiles", and 39A name did NOT offer enlightenment.  

Anyone here refer to FOIL as AL?  ....I thought not.

I started this solve at 61A, so it solved very smoothly until I read the cocktail ingredients.  Srsly??  Two Mystified UGHs on that one.   Life is too short to get involved with Southern Comfort, I'm pretty sure.  
This year's fruitcake is being "Bourbonized."  With the real thing.
A fun puzzle, fittingly on the day after Dick ALlen was finally selected to the Baseball HOF.
Re: 16A; In Soviet Russia, when they say, "break a leg," you break leg.

Who knew that the CIA had such a puckish sense of humor?  It's not tricky and it's not challenging, but 31D -- which gave me a delicious bit of info I didn't know -- is one of my favorite clues ever.

I also love the Stephen King quote at 62A.

The theme was a SNORE -- but as long as a puzzle is fun, I don't really care about the theme.  And, because I am one of the world's laziest people, my original answer to "apt rhyme for 'bore' " was CHORE.

Lovely clue for TUBA.  Do I care what the crossing letter between the abbrev. at 27D and the middle name at 39A is?  No I don't.  My small act of protest is to leave it unfilled.

I thought this was considerably harder than most Mondays, so I rather liked it despite the tepid theme.

What's deep in a pit?  

Good one!
Not a Monday puzzle level of difficulty. Some really bad clues here
Fun start to the solving week!

I wish people would stop saying that this (or any) puzzle was too difficult, and instead say that it was too difficult "for me."

I didn't think this puzzle was difficult at all; it was a pleasant and enjoyable Monday puzzle...for me.

Nice debut, Elliot!
Agree with many that this was difficult for a Monday: POGS, ONBLAST, HUNDO. LIAISE.

I was a little confused why my crossings seemed off:  ALABAMASLFMMER; LID; ROUNGE; ALUMINEMFOIL, but then I realized:  The constructor is using the common understanding that ACLU is still a , when I was using the contemporary understanding that it is no longer one, and that mantle has been passed to FIRE.  Oh well, maybe next time!
Went to solve the online Sunday puzzle late yesterday (Sunday) afternoon and it was gone, replaced by the Monday puzzle. Does that frustrate anyone else?
52 down was a delight! Bore/snore. Great Monday puzzle. Thank you.
Cute, quick Monday. And that song will be definitely be stuck in my head all day!

Ok I‚Äôm crying foul on ‚ÄúPULLON‚Äù pants üòÇüòÇ 
What pants are NOT pull on?

This one brought a smile to my face. A clever puzzle with some fun clues that require a bit of pondering (e.g. What's deep in a pit?). This one took me a tad bit longer to solve than my usual time for a Monday.

Thanks, Elliot, for all your work on this crossword!

Another wonderful debut among many of late.
Really miss Will Shortz's editting.

Strands #281
‚ÄúQuiet at first‚Äù
üîµüîµüü°üîµ
üîµüîµüîµ

I'm usually quiet at first. Then you get to know me.

Shush on the spoilers until we get below the fold with our replies.
WHAT A DEBUT!!!!! CONGRATS! IF ONLY SUNDAYS WERE THIS GOOD ACROSS THE BOARD!!!! IF FOLKS DON'T GET HOW GOOD THIS IS THAT'S THEIR LOSS NOT OURS!

I agree with today's column; this was a lot of fun and a great way to start the week. The reference to the great song by Paul Simon and the "tuba" clue made me smile, too!

Thanks @Elliot Caroll for an entertaining Monday puzzle; I'm looking forward to your next one.
Thanks Elliott! This made for a fun Monday. I tried making a crossword puzzle once and had to bulldoze it after about five words -- it's harder than it looks üò≤ Good job!
Great Monday crossword for a rainy day like the one I am having. Enjoying some fresh biscuits on the sofa with a couple of candles and a nice view of the Christmas tree. Very cozy, thank you! üòä

Enjoyed the bit of extra challenge on Monday, and did the puzzle with a BEANIE Baby from my youth on the nightstand next mo me.

I wonder if we'll ever see HUNDO clued in its Pok√©mon GO sense.

Here's a poser: I solved today's puzzle in the app on my iPad, which says I solved it in just under X minutes.

On the NYT website, the Stats bar graph has X minutes. 

But if I go on the website to "admire" my solved puzzle, the pop-up tells me it took me about 3X to solve the puzzle. 

Weird.
not against this puzzle as a nyt crossword at all...very clever. but I do think it's a bit too difficult for the monday puzzle.
I liked deep in a pit. I had the first letter and thot of TAR. Nope too short. Then later as I came back it dawned on me an orchestra pit. Eureka!! My two second high for the day.
I finished the puzzle last night and this morning the grid was wiped clean. I have contacted NYTimes Games techs, but so far, no response. Did anyone else have this weirdness?
What a clever, fun puzzle! A perfect Monday!
Is "onblast" one word or two? On second thought, I don't want to know.
Nobody says "hundo." I will not be gaslit.

What a great puzzle, and a terrific debut for Elliot Caroll. My favorite clue was ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs deep in a pit?‚Äù  Such a delightful misdirect. And Elliot‚Äôs Constructor Notes were just as entertaining as her puzzle. I hope we‚Äôll be seeing much more from her.

Although I've completed every puzzle since March 2023, I didn't get the gold star streak because life happens and some of those puzzles were finished a day or 2 late. However, I have been diligent, and can proudly say my gold star streak now extends to 365 days! One year! Woohoo! I've been looking forward to this for the last year. We need to take pleasure in the little wins in life. 

Looking forward to joining the 500 and 1000 day clubs next.

Steve,

Easter egg?

Some consider another notable last name for AL as (52D) an [Apt rhyme for "bore"] and SNORE.
@Steve L You got it, and thank you! Appreciate you sharing it here. ü´°

@Steve L 
Oh, I missed that additional layer of meaning too! Makes it much more satisfying. Thank you for that!
D'oh! I can always rely on the solving community to catch the deeper meaning of it AL. The column has been updated to include a properly full explanation; thanks for spotting!
@Michael I was blanking on his name for some reason. Remembered his brother being "Super Dave" Osborne, and their real last name being Einstein. Took a while for AB to finally click in. Strange.

@Joe V

How did I not know these things?? And I thought I was a fan. Talking about Albert Brooks just makes me want to rewatch Broadcast News. Such a quotable movie.

Paul Moore: It must be nice to always believe you know better, to always think you're the smartest person in the room.
Jane Craig: No. It's awful.

@Justin 
Not too long ago I posted Joan Cusack's delivering the video tape scene.

@Justin 
‚ÄúI can sing while I read. I am singing and reading, both!‚Äù I confess, I have quoted that line more than once, sometimes changing the reading part to fit whatever I‚Äôm doing. Such a great movie, and Albert Brooks is so great in it. I may join you in that rewatch.
@Vaer Ok, I'll meet you at the place near the thing where we went that time.
Same. This is the first time I‚Äôve seen two unknown (to me) slang terms in one puzzle. Won‚Äôt be the last time, with my 68th birthday fast approaching.
@dutchiris Pretty sure I never in my 30 years online saw anyone use "On blast" in that sense, confounded me.

dutchiris,

This may be nearing the hundoth time I‚Äôve seen that one,
but happy to tell the world, the first ever for ONBLAST.

@dutchiris I am with you.  Who calls $100.00  "hundo"?
I'm from the C-Note and Benjamin generation, I guess.

@Comet 

Hundred may be hard for some people to say‚ÄîI've often heard hunner, hunnert and hunderd, but never hundo.
@Anita Thank you so much! I actually rewatched the Simon and Garfunkel in Central Park special just the other day, but I think I‚Äôll throw on Paul‚Äôs tomorrow thanks to your comment.
@Justin You have great taste :)
@Eric Hougland Thanks so much!

@Alex 
This was a much harder puzzle for Monday.  Beginners, don‚Äôt be discouraged.

@Andrew I'm tempted to say yes, possibly. According to Webster's, the word was coined in the late 1920's, so is almost a hundred years old, and I feel like it's been fairly common for decades. 
On the other hand, I had to get POGS from the crossings, and have never heard ON BLAST.
@Andrew TIL that I've been spelling it wrong! Okay, I don't know if I've ever written it out before, but I didn't know that it has two i's.
@Joan Delighted to hear you enjoyed it! I hope so too :)
Maybe the horns

@B In his own words: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going through my repertoire and reducing a lot of the choices I make to acoustic versions,‚Äù he noted. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all much quieter. It‚Äôs not ‚ÄòYou Can Call Me Al.‚Äô That‚Äôs gone. I can‚Äôt do that one.‚Äù In other words, probably the horns. üòâ (As @Mike said!) https://ultimateclassicrock.com/paul-simon-wont-play-you-can-call-me-al/ The article also mentions the work Simon is doing to support hearing loss research. But for him, I can't imagine he'll improve to a point where he can reprise a song like this. One can hope!
@Vaer Thank you so much! Sadly my Beanie Babies collection retirement plan was a bust, but I still have Pinky the Flamingo in storage.
@Valerie Thank you!

@Marshall Walthew Thanks so much for this lovely comment. My fave song of his is probably "Still Crazy After All (AL?) These Years". I've also never had an Alabama Slammer myself, but might have to tomorrow. Cheers to you!

@Marshall Walthew 

I was initially startled that SLOE COMFORTABLE SCREW would both fit in and be accepted by the NYTXW.

Spmm,

Heh heh.

My mother used to tell us of an odd teacher she had, who considered herself very old-world-refined. She insisted on her students learning by oral repetition the ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù pronunciation of both ‚Äúaluminium‚Äù, and the equally extra-syllabic (in her world) ‚Äúpeninsulia‚Äù.

Bill,

The mongrelizing (and hybrid-invigourating) effect of being at the confluence of three powerful  linguistic and cultural rivers is everywhere in this land, but un-predictable. The metric/imperial mashup I have and see most is all in for degrees  Celsius (except cooking, cuz ovens and old recipes), but situational for miles/kilometres and pounds/kilograms.

Apart from a couple of UK expats, no one I know or hear says or spells it ‚Äúaluminium‚Äù (with the extra i, in case autocorrect goes rogue after I hit submit).

And I am center and meter bi-curious.

@JohnWM https://www.noslangues-ourlanguages.gc.ca/en/quiz/canadian-spelling-pretty-tricky-eng My Partner and I only got 8/10 )-:ID (That is a little frownie face wearing a to/uque, in case you couldn't tell.)

@Bill 
That was fun. I got 7,8, and 9 wrong.  (I thought they were talking about a chef's hat.)

Bill,

Thanks for that, I guess. I also got 8/10, though I will say I just clicked the wrong choice by mistake on one of those two (theater centre), but actually was mistaken on ‚Äúhumorist‚Äù.

So, I am packing my bags in shame and moving to‚Ä¶ the mid-Atlantic?

Bill,

And yes, that vigour I was in-ating was a hybrid by design (but these so-called rules of ‚Äúwith the u except with certain affixes‚Äù are just irritating and a thorn in my poor memory). I have to check every time for such things, not to mention more common words.

@Mike 

Into the fridge? What a cold shot, he replied, heatedly.

Mike,

Que saran, saran.

I see the constructor is replying to our comments today and now I feel a bit rotten about my post. Elliot Caroll, please don't take my criticism personally. You are obviously a much more talented and intelligent person than I am, and your puzzle is actually quite the feat of construction. Still, IMO it is not a Monday puzzle, and what I was objecting to was the day the puzzle ran on, given its contents. You clearly have a knack for misdirection, which would be brilliant on Wednesday or later. Just please, whatever day your puzzles feature on, have mercy on international solvers and please try limit the trivia üòâ

@Andrzej --  Did you finally finish that Saturday LAT puzzle?  Just wondering if it finally opened up ...




Et tu emu.

@Andrzej -- Hah! It sure would have.  







Et tu, emu.

@Andrzej 

Tsk.  I never took you for a whiner! 
And now you didn't even stand behind your protests due to the presence of the constructor.
Gotta own those posts!

Just picking on you because the emus let YOU have as many entries as you want....

@Mean Old Lady 

Emus ate my original reply to your post just now...

@Bea 

You do have a point there. Still, directness is my thing, and again, I was aiming it at the puzzle running on Monday, not at the constructor or the puzzle as such. Seeing how nice and positive the replies by Elliot Caroll were, I just felt I should make that doubly clear.

@Joe

@HeathieJ 

I loved Alabama Slammers when I was... Let's just say at an age where I based my interest in drinking establishments on whether or not they carded-?! 

Back then I also liked that cocktail's tart cousin, a Teeny Weeny Woo (also called a Woo Woo). Both were red. And sweet. And strooong! 

Funny enough, when cosmos became a thing, I wasn't interested. Maybe I'd had my fill of cranberry with those Woos... 

You'll appreciate that my favorite drink -- back then and for years -- was Jack and Coke. Now I prefer bourbon, usually straight. But you can judge how sweet I liked them back then!!

@Rich in Atlanta As threatened: The other puzzle is a Wednesday from February 2, 2000. What struck me about this one is that the theme answers were essentially un-clued, other than the fact that they were linked together. Specifically, the four theme clues were: "Beginning of a quip." "Quip, part 2." "Quip, part 3." "End of the quip." And.. the four referenced theme answers: TOERRISHUMANBUT ITTAKESA COMPUTER TOREALLYSCREWUP Just baffled as to understanding how in the world you could work that out. Would have to be all of the down answers. Just don't recall seeing anything like that before. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/2/2000&g=17&d=A I'll shut up now. ...

@Steve I say tinfoil in my head when I think of it, but translate to aluminum foil if I have to say it out loud to someone else. Tinfoil's lodged deeper in my brain because I learned it first. It's also more fun to say, especially if you're talking about conspiracy theorists; wearing tinfoil hats they're just silly but if they were wearing aluminum foil hats? Maybe a more serious threat and if it's a family member you'd feel compelled to call the guys in the white coats. And now I have a different earworm. The word/phrase you were attempting to use to describe the ACLU did not display. I, for one, am not at all clear what should go there -- or why the ACLU is (no longer??) a free speech group?

@G 

I don't get it either... Are they saying that the ACLU is no longer American?
FIRE and ACLU are two separate organizations.  The American Civil Liberties Union has not changed its name.  FIRE is the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression, a distinct entity.

@Nancy J. I would guess that NY Expat's point is that the ACLU is no longer as dedicated to free speech as it once was. https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-aclu-retreats-from-free-expression-1529533065 (Apologies for linking to something behind a paywall, but the introduction to the commentary gives one the general idea.)

@Eric Hougland 

Very helpful intro paragraph, thanks! And from all the way back in June, 2018. Noted that it is an Op-Ed, not reporting, so the commentary has a specific slant:

"The American Civil Liberties Union has explicitly endorsed the view that free speech can harm 'marginalized' groups by undermining their civil rights.  ...  This is presented as an explanation rather than a change of policy, and free-speech advocates know the ACLU has already lost its zeal for vigorously defending the speech it hates. ACLU leaders previously avoided acknowledging that retreat, however, in the apparent hope of preserving its reputation as the nation‚Äôs premier champion of the First Amendment."

So if the ACLU did explicitly change their guidelines, the clue as written can be quibbled with -- but I'd say ultimately is still correct along *crosswords* guidelines!
